Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) Scanner for Computer Vision Research and Interdisciplinary Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a Leica ScanStation P30, aims to develop methods for aligning two dimensional (2D) and three dimensional (3D) data and to assemble educational tools using the produced 3D visualizations. The LIDAR (LIght Detection And Ranging) scanner will be used by professors and students studying and performing research in the fields of computer science, film, and art at the institution. The group builds on the researcher's existing work that creates navigable 3D environments from sets of 2D pictures and videos that are registered with 3D LIDAR scans. With the instrumentation this project would enable the following intertwined goals.
(i) Build an interdisciplinary research group to further study how to describe and register multi-modality data, or data obtained with different cameras and sensors.
(ii) Use the developed methods to build educational 3D applications with collaborators in film and history.
(iii) Develop new, cross-disciplinary courses that use the proposed scanner to provide access for many students to the state-of-the-art technology.
The developed courses would help the investigator train and recruit students for her research lab that can work on interdisciplinary projects.

Although at present collecting and storing both 2D images and 3D LIDAR scans might be easier and more economical, fusing such multi-modality data remains challenging. Confusion is often created in automatic matching methods by the repetition and ambiguity that often occur in man-made scenes as well as the variety of properties on different renderings of the same subject. Image sets collected over a period of time during which lighting conditions and scene content may have changed, different artistic rendering, as well as varying sensor types (Camera, LIDAR, etc.), can all contribute to visual variations in data sets. However, by incorporating contextual information to visualize the regional properties that intuitively exist in each imagery source, the proponent has successfully addressed many of the obstacles. Her research group will also study how human perception can be used for registering 3D LIDAR data with other types of visual information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded the purchase of a Leica ScanStation P30 under the instrument acquisition track of the Major Research Instrumentation program (MRI).  The LIDAR (LIght Detection And Ranging) scanner is being used to scan and obtain accurate 3D point clouds of significant buildings and landscapes in southeastern North Carolina.  The PI and her students have incorporated this data into projects focused on aligning 2D images with 3D scans to create photorealistic models for data visualization purposes.  The main three goals of this project were 1) Incorporate LIDAR technology into computer science curriculum at UNCW, 2) Use funded equipment in starting up an undergraduate research lab, and 3) Use funded equipment for multi-disciplinary research projects (computer science with art, film, education, history etc.).  All three of these goals were accomplished during the duration of this project.

 

Broader Impacts:  The PI introduced and assigned student LIDAR-based projects in both dedicated computer science and cross-disciplinary classes at the University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW).  She has incorporated LIDAR technology into her courses entitled Introduction to Computer Science (for first-year computing students), Computer Graphics (for upper-level computer science and digital arts students), Computer Vision for 3D Reconstruction (a new course designed by the PI for upper-level computer science and digital arts students), and Digital Visual Effects (for upper-level computer science, digital arts, and film studies students).  The 100+ students who have taken these classes with the PI so far have learned about state-of-the-art 3D scanning technology that is being used across the surveying, robotics, and autonomous vehicles industries.  They have learned about the format of 3D data and the strengths and weaknesses of this technology.  Students have additionally had the opportunity to explore the uses of 3D scanning technology in artistic and historic applications such as taking archeological measurements of ancient sites and preserving Renaissance statues.  The PI has anecdotal reason to believe that incorporating this NSF-funded technology into standard coursework has helped inspire students in their computing studies to continue pushing their boundaries.

During the timeline of this project, the PI had the chance to engage in several community outreach events in which she discussed and demonstrated the NSF-funded LIDAR scanner with the public.  She gave a lecture and demonstration during UNCW’s College Day, a weekend event for seniors in the community to attend lectures given by professors across the university.  She also brought the LIDAR scanner to the Teen Science Café at the Whiteville Museum of Natural History to teach younger students about 3D scanning at one of the organization’s monthly lectures from STEM professionals.

 

Intellectual Merit:  The support provided by this project has helped the PI, a junior faculty, build a research lab within UNCW’s Department of Computer Science.  Incorporating the funded equipment has aided her in training and recruiting student research assistants from classes.  This project has also provided a framework for the PI to be an active mentor in UNCW’s First Year Research Experience program in which she trains freshman computer science majors in 2D and 3D imagery collection and data cleaning techniques.  During the duration of this project the PI published work on 2D-3D image alignment and photorealistic modeling in IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing and Springer The Visual Computer.  The PI’s research group has developed methods for visualizing 2D photographs and 3D LIDAR scans of both urban and natural environments in a style that can be easily registered automatically.  Her team is also working on building an extensive dataset of different types of 2D visual documentation and 3D scans that pushes the bounds of current registration methods.  During the project, the PI also made contributions to a textbook for film studies students by developing a 3D photorealistic environment as the basis of a virtual training module. 

The PI is using the outcomes of this project and the funded equipment to participate in a subsequent interdisciplinary NSF grant within the Innovative Technology for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program.  The PI is working with other Computer Science and Education professors and students on creating virtual environments for K-12 students to encourage pursuing careers in STEM.  The PI’s work in creating 3D virtual models of outdoor environments is being used to reconstruct significant landscapes and buildings in coastal North Carolina to make this environment more accessible to young students.  The PI is also in preliminary planning stages with other UNCW professors and regional professionals in Art History and the State Division of Historic Sites on projects involving aligning historical documentation and artwork with 3D models to assist in data visualization.
